newsitem.title: FRANCE: Aerospatiale, Renault develop light plane engines.
newsitem.headline: Aerospatiale, Renault develop light plane engines.

text.p: French state-owned aerospace firm Aerospatiale and carmaker Renault have formed a venture to develop a new generation of engines for light aircraft, the companies said on Wednesday.

The 50-50 venture, Societe de Motorisations Aeronautiques, expects to apply for certification of the new engines, ranging from 180 to 300 horsepower, by the spring of 1998, the two companies said in a joint statement.
They declined to give financial details on the venture but said it was expected to reach a capacity of 100 motors annually.

Renault Sport, which boasts five Formula 1 world championships, will initially develop the motors for light planes built by Aerospatiale's subsidiary Socata, which sells them to pilot schools, tourism firms and shuttle operators.
The venture will subsequently seek more customers.

"Under the terms of this partnership, which has been prepared since 1995, Socata and Renault plan to propose to clients a range of motors with new technology responding to environmental, cost and reliability demands," the firms said.
The motors will be as powerful as the current generation but quieter, 50 percent more durable, and they will run on kerosene, cutting operating expenses.
Socata chairman Yves Michot told a news conference that the venture would help the firm boost plane sales.
"We'll have an entirely new product range which will allow us to develop sales in a sector that has suffered badly in recent years," he said.
He said market opportunities were presented by increased environmental and frontier surveillance and pilot training.
Prices would be at current market levels, with the 200 horsepower engine priced at between 150,000 francs and 200,000 francs.
